topic.title: Adding an Object Storage Daemon (OSD) Node

section.p: You may have a need to add an object storage daemon (OSD) node for additional Ceph capacity or another purpose and these steps will help you achieve this.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: You should have one or more baremetal servers that meet the minimum hardware requirements for an object storage daemon (OSD) node which are documented in the Hardware Support Matrix.

section.title: Adding an Object Storage Daemon (OSD) Node
section.p: These steps will show you how to add the new OSD node to your servers.yml file and then run the playbooks that update your cloud configuration. You will run these playbooks from the lifecycle manager.

ol.li: Log in to your lifecycle manager.
Checkout the site branch of your local git so you can begin to make the necessary edits: cd ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data git checkout site

In the same directory, edit your servers.yml file to include the details about your new OSD node(s). Copy and paste the section for an existing server having the OSD-ROLE role and edit the values to match the new server being added.
For example, if you already had a cluster of three OSD nodes and needed to add a fourth one you would add your details to the bottom of the file in this format: # Ceph OSD Nodes - id: osd4 ip-addr: 192.168.10.9 role: OSD-ROLE server-group: RACK1 nic-mapping: MY-2PORT-SERVER mac-addr: 8b:f6:9e:ca:3b:78 ilo-ip: 192.168.9.9 ilo-password: password ilo-user: admin
You can find detailed descriptions of these fields here. You will need to verify that the ip-addr value you choose for this node does not conflict with any other IP address in your cloud environment. You can confirm this by checking the ~/helion/my_cloud/info/address_info.yml file on your lifecycle manager.

In your control_plane.yml file you will need to check the values for member-count, min-count, and max-count, if you specified them, to ensure that they match up with your new total node count. So for example, if you had previously specified member-count: 3 and are adding a fourth OSD node, you will need to change that value to member-count: 4.
See Input Model - Control Plane for more details.
Commit the changes to git: git commit -a -m "Add node <name>"
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Run the ready deployment playbook: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Add the new node into Cobbler: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml

Then you can image the node: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml -e nodelist=<node name> If you don't know the <node name> already, you can get it by using sudo cobbler system list
Before proceeding, you may want to take a look at info/server_info.yml to see if the assignment of the node you have added is what you expect. It may not be, as nodes will not be numbered consecutively if any have previously been removed. This is to prevent loss of data; the config processor retains data about removed nodes and keeps their ID numbers from being reallocated. See the Persisted Server Allocations section in
Input Model for information on how this works.

Run the following series of playbooks complete the deployment of your additional OSD node(s) to your Ceph cluster: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml --tags "generate_hosts_file" ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-deploy.yml --limit <host_var name> If you don't know the <host_var name> already, you can get it by looking in the ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible/host_vars directory.
